chapter.title: 128 Curvularia, Exophiala, Scedosporium, Sporothrix, and Other Melanized Fungi

sect1.title: 128 Curvularia, Exophiala, Scedosporium, Sporothrix, and Other Melanized Fungi
sect1.para: JOSEP GUARRO, HUGO MADRID, AND SYBREN DE HOOG

This chapter covers most of the agents of phaeohyphomycosis, chromoblastomycosis, and sporotrichosis, as well as a number of agents of superficial and cutaneous disease. The genera discussed in this chapter belong to the ascomycetous orders Botryosphaeriales (Lasiodiplodia, Macrophomina, and Neoscytalidium), Calosphaeriales (Pleurostoma), Capnodiales (Hortaea), Cladosporiales (Cladosporium), Chaetothyriales (Anthopsis, Arthrocladium, Cladophialophora, Cyphellophora, Exophiala, Fonsecaea, Knufia, Phialophora, Rhinocladiella, and Veronaea), Diaporthales (Diaporthe), Dothideales (Aureobasidium and Hormonema), Microascales (Lomentospora, Microascus, Scedosporium, Scopulariopsis, and Triadelphia), Ophiostomatales (Knoxdaviesia, Ophiostoma, and Sporothrix), Pleosporales (Alternaria, Bipolaris, Curvularia, Exserohilum, Gambiomyces, Hongkongmyces, Meanderella, Phoma, and Pleurophomopsis), Sordariales (Phialemonium [discussed in chapter 124], Podospora, and “Papulaspora”), Thyridiales (Thyridium), Togniniales (Phaeoacremonium), and Venturiales (Scolecobasidium and Verruconis). In this chapter, the genera are treated according to their ordinal relationships (Table 1). Definitions of mycological terms are provided in chapter 117.

The term “dematiaceous” applies to fungi with brown (melanin-containing) hyphae and/or conidia in general (1). Also, the term “phaeoid” indicates brown hyphae; “phaeohyphomycosis” is an umbrella term for infections caused by moulds that display brownish hyphae, pseudohyphae, or yeast-like cells, or a combination of these forms, in host tissue (2). Conidia might be observed in infected tissue, but they are extremely uncommon (3). “Black yeasts and relatives” is preferably used to indicate members of Chaetothyriales and Dothideales only. The black yeasts are not a formal taxonomic group, but the term is applied to a wide range of phylogenetically diverse melanized ascomycetous and basidiomycetous fungi that are able to produce budding yeast-like cells, often accompanied by filaments, at some stage in their life cycle (2, 4).

Pleoanamorphism (multiple morphological forms) is particularly striking in members of the black yeasts and in the generaScedosporium and Triadelphia (2, 5). These fungi are able to produce more than one asexual form of propagation (“synanamorphs” or “synasexual morphs”). These asexual states often were given separate names in the past, resulting in significant confusion. Further complication resulted from the fact that some fungi show either asexual or sexual morphs during different phases of their life cycle, which also used to be named separately (1, 2). Nowadays, fungal taxonomy is undergoing important changes because of the application of the “one fungus = one name” or “unitary nomenclature” concept, which should lead to a single name for a particular fungal species, giving priority to the oldest or most widely used name, depending on each particular case (6). Independently propagating asexual forms, then, are no longer assigned formal names, but the former generic names are used as descriptive nouns. Only a small percentage of clinically relevant fungal species are known to produce a sexual state (“teleomorph”), characterized by the formation of fruiting bodies with meiotic ascospores, under routine laboratory conditions. For each organism, only a single sexual state can be produced (2).

sect2.title: TAXONOMY AND DESCRIPTION OF THE AGENTS
Lasiodiplodia
sect2.para: Lasiodiplodia is a phytopathogenic coelomycete genus characterized by more or less spherical, thick-walled, often confluent fruiting bodies filled with asexual conidia. The conidia initially are ellipsoidal and hyaline but gradually become brown and develop a median septum at maturation. Lasiodiplodia theobromae (Fig. 1c to e) (previously known as Botryodiplodia theobromae) is the only species well documented as an agent of human disease (7–9).

sect1.title: Macrophomina
sect1.para: Macrophomina phaseolina is a widespread plant pathogen affecting various economically important crops. It occasionally also infects immunocompromised humans. The fungus produces both dark sclerotia and pycnidia (globose to flask-shaped structures containing conidiogenous cells) on plant tissue, but clinical isolates produce only melanized mycelium and sclerotia in culture. Identification of this species is therefore mainly based on DNA sequence analyses (10, 11).

sect1.title: Neoscytalidium
sect1.para: Neoscytalidium dimidiatum (formerly known as Scytalidium dimidiatum) is a plant pathogen associated with a broad spectrum of infections in humans, especially affecting skin and nails. The fungus produces arthroconidia in culture, and some isolates also produce pycnidia under appropriate growth conditions (2). The coelomycetous synasexual morph has often been referred to as Nattrassia mangiferae, previously known as Hendersonula toruloidea (10). However, molecular studies have demonstrated that N. dimidiatum and N. mangiferae are two different species and that the latter actually belongs in the genus Neofusicoccum (12).

Inside multilocular fruit bodies, hyaline, ellipsoidal conidia develop, which in part become brownish and have one or two septa. In culture, usually only a rapidly growing, jet black, floccose anamorph with dark arthroconidia is seen (Fig. 1a and b); the pycnidia are produced only after 2 months of growth on a moistened plant leaf or on nutrient-poor culture medium (2). Melaninless mutants, which also show reduced conidiation, were until recently referred to as Neoscytalidium hyalinum (= Scytalidium hyalinum), but this name is currently considered a synonym of N. dimidiatum (2, 10, 13). Recently, a second clinically relevant species was described, N. oculi, which does not produce pycnidia in culture and is able to produce biofilms in vitro (14).

sect1.title: Calosphaeriales
sect1.para: Some melanized phialidic fungi were segregated fromPhialophora on molecular and morphological grounds; these fungi now constitute small islands of clinical significance in the order Calosphaeriales, which otherwise contains plant-associated moulds. Infections are mostly of a traumatic nature and are supposed to originate directly from the woody plant material of the fungal habitat (2, 15).

sect2.title: Pleurostoma
sect2.para: Pleurostoma is a genus of mainly wood-inhabiting fungi. Hyphae are dark and bear pale, tapering phialides that may be single or aggregated in dense brushes; hyaline, slimy conidia are produced through small or large collarettes (2). Pleurostoma repens was occasionally reported from subcutaneous infections in humans. The second species of the genus also involved in human infections is Pleurostoma richardsiae (Fig. 2h and i) (syn. Phialophora richardsiae), a soft-rot fungus on wood (15). Pleurostoma ochraceum is exceptional in producing yellow grains in mycetomas, which previously had been interpreted exclusively as being bacterial (16). Clinically relevant Pleurostoma species were, until recently, named with the asexual morph name “Pleurostomophora” (15), but they were transferred to the sexually typified genus Pleurostoma in order to apply unitary nomenclature (17).

sect2.title: Hortaea
sect2.para: Members of the genusHortaea have rather wide hyphae that become profusely septate during growth of the fungus, and they exhibit annellidic conidiogenesis from broad scars (2). The halophilic species Hortaea werneckii (Fig. 1f) lives in seawater, molluscs, evaporation ponds at the subtropical seashore, and other saline habitats and causes superficial infections. This fungus characteristically produces yeast-like, aseptate or septate elements (18). The clinical picture is known as tinea nigra (2) and is discussed in chapter 127. A second species, H. thailandica, has been described from leaves of Syzygium in Thailand (19).

sect2.title: Cladosporium
sect2.para: Species ofCladosporium, such as Cladosporium cladosporioides (Fig. 3c and d), C. oxysporum, and C. sphaerospermum, are among the most common fungi in air and represent extremely common contaminants in the clinical laboratory, as well as allergens (2). The genus is characterized by fragile branching acropetal chains of one-celled or septate conidia with dark scars; sexual states are rarely produced in culture. Several cladosporium-like genera have been described in recent years, but true Cladosporium spp. show distinctive conidiogenous loci with a raised dome-shaped central zone surrounded by a rim. This has been referred to as the coronate scar type in literature (20). Cladosporium spp. can be isolated from soil, plants, and water and have also been described as occasional human opportunists. Such cases need thorough evaluation, as infection by Cladosporium is highly unlikely. Several species probably associated with human disease are described in the reference book by de Hoog et al. (2). In a study by Sandoval-Denis et al. (21), 92 Cladosporium isolates obtained from diverse clinical specimens in the United States were characterized by multilocus sequence analyses and morphology. The most frequently identified species were C. halotolerans, C. tenuissimum, and C. pseudocladosporioides.

sect1.title: Chaetothyriales
sect1.para: The rather small order Chaetothyriales is clinically highly relevant because many of its members are able to cause infections in humans (2). They are apparently widely distributed in nature, although they are difficult to isolate from environmental samples because of their slow growth (22).

sect1.title: Anthopsis
sect1.para: Anthopsis is a small genus with peculiar ampulliform phialides that mostly appear inverted, with the collarettes near the base. The type species is Anthopsis deltoidea, a soilborne fungus with triangular conidia (23–25).

sect1.title: Arthrocladium
sect1.para: The genusArthrocladium currently includes four species mostly occurring on plant material and ant nests. One of them, Arthrocladium fulminans, has been reported from infections in immunocompromised and otherwise healthy patients. Cultures of this fungus do not produce conidia, but moniliform hyphae and chlamydospore-like structures can be observed. Species identification relies on DNA sequence comparisons (26, 27).

sect1.title: Cladophialophora
sect1.para: The genusCladophialophora is characterized by the production of dry, rather coherent chains of conidia that usually lack dark scars. Conidiophores are mostly undifferentiated. This genus contains 11 pathogenic species (Table 1), many of which are known almost exclusively from humans and other warm-blooded animals (2, 28, 29). However, members of this genus also can be found in soil and on plant material (22, 28). The most significant species are Cladophialophora bantiana and C. carrionii. Cladophialophora bantiana, a remarkable neurotropic mould, is recognizable by very long, poorly branched conidial chains and by an ability to grow at 40°C (Fig. 2a and b; see also Fig. 5b to d). This fungus can cause central nervous system phaeohyphomycosis and other infections in otherwise healthy individuals (2). It is considered a biosafety level 3 (BSL-3) microorganism, which needs to be handled with precaution within a biosafety cabinet. It has a characteristic 558-bp intron at position 1768 of the small-subunit (SSU) ribosomal operon (30). Cladophialophora carrionii is a common agent of chromoblastomycosis, with small conidia in profusely branched chains, and sometimes shows a phialidic synasexual state (2, 31). A recently described soilborne species, Cladophialophora cabanerensis, produces abundant phialides in culture but lacks the typical acropetal branches of holoblastic conidia (32). According to current taxonomic concepts (2), this fungus might need to be reallocated to the genus Phialophora. Several clinically relevant Cladophialophora spp. were studied by de Hoog et al. (2) and Badali et al. (28, 29). They may be difficult to differentiate phenotypically, and recent studies have revealed the existence of morphologically similar environmental siblings (22, 31). Accurate species identification in this group of fungi, therefore, should be supported by DNA sequence analyses.

sect2.title: Cyphellophora
sect2.para: Cyphellophora (including clinical species previously placed in Pseudomicrodochium) is a rather uncommon genus of phialidic hyphomycetes inhabiting soil, plant material, and river sediments (22, 33). Traditionally, they have been characterized by slender, curved, transversely septate conidia (2). Several phialophora-like species with one-celled conidia proved to cluster with Cyphellophora spp. and were therefore transferred to this genus (22, 34). All these fungi reside in Cyphellophoraceae, whereas the type species of Phialophora is a member of Herpotrichiellaceae (33, 35). Cultures of Cyphellophora spp. are evenly melanized and show limited expansion growth. Conidia are generally produced from poorly developed collarettes alongside the hyphae, but discrete phialides also may be observed (36, 37). Clinically relevant species, such as Cyphellophora pluriseptata (Fig. 2e to g), C. europaea, C. laciniata, and C. reptans, are rare etiological agents of superficial mycoses (2, 33). Cyphellophora ludoviensis and C. suttonii, on the other hand, have been reported from subcutaneous infections (36–38). The incidence of these fungi is probably low, but they are likely to be underdiagnosed.

sect2.title: Exophiala
sect2.para: Exophiala is the main genus of clinically relevant black yeasts. Strains usually show a high degree of morphological plasticity. Most isolates initially produce a yeast-like thallus but subsequently produce regular hyphae as well as filaments with frequent constrictions referred to as moniliform hyphae or torulose hyphae. As a result, colonies are moist and slimy at first, becoming velvety to woolly with age. The process of conidium production is typically annellidic, from narrow, inconspicuous scars or extensions (2, 4). Occasionally, a very slowly growing, meristematic morphology (“Sarcinomyces”) can be observed (2, 39). Fresh isolates or strains cultivated on nutritionally deficient media, such as oatmeal agar or synthetic nutrient-poor agar, frequently produce conidia in chains and may produce scattered or compacted phialides with huge collarettes (4, 39, 40). The most frequently reported species are Exophiala dermatitidis (Fig. 2) and E. jeanselmei sensu lato. The latter has been subdivided into a number of taxa, such as E. oligosperma, E. bergeri, and E. xenobiotica, on molecular grounds; they are difficult to distinguish morphologically (41, 42). Exophiala dermatitidis is recognizable morphologically by phialides without collarettes, which are wide, and by conidiogenous cells with scar-like, very short annellated zones. In addition, growth at 40°C and the inability to assimilate nitrate are characteristic (39, 43). The related species E. phaeomuriformis differs by having a growth maximum at 38°C (2, 39). The less frequently isolated species E. spinifera can be recognized by the presence of large, stiff conidiophores (2). A similar species with reduced conidiogenous cells, E. attenuata, was described (41). DNA sequence analyses are strongly recommended for a reliable identification of Exophiala spp.

In a BLAST search (unpublished data, H. Madrid), the internal transcribed spacer (ITS) sequence of the ex-type strain ofPhaeoannellomyces elegans, CBS 122.95, showed 99.64% sequence identity to the ITS of the ex-type strain of Exophiala sideris, CBS 121828. Phaeoannellomyces elegans is the type species of Phaeoannellomyces and represents an uncommon etiological agent of phaeohyphomycosis in humans (44). This fungus produces abundant dematiaceous yeast cells and blastic, mainly annellidic conidiogenous cells (45). These characteristics and its phylogenetic affinities to the Herpotrichiellaceae suggest that Phaeoannellomyces might be a putative synonym of Exophiala. Further studies are required to test this hypothesis and to determine whether E. sideris and P. elegans are synonyms. In such case, it would be necessary to reallocate P. elegans to Exophiala as “Exophiala elegans.”

sect2.title: Fonsecaea
sect2.para: The genusFonsecaea currently includes five pathogenic species, roughly characterized by dry, usually short, and more or less compact chains of conidia. In culture, Fonsecaea species mostly have one morphological form, but they may produce additional phialophora-like phialides with collarettes and rhinocladiella-like sympodial conidiophores (2). No budding cells are produced on routine media. Fonsecaea pedrosoi (Fig. 2k, including the mutant F. compacta) is one of the main etiologic agents of human chromoblastomycosis. Two other agents of this disease which are also implicated in phaeohyphomycosis, F. monophora and F. nubica, are morphologically indistinguishable but are recognized by DNA sequence analyses (46, 47). A morphologically similar species, F. pugnacius, was described from a case of chromoblastomycosis that disseminated to the central nervous system. Remarkably, the fungus produced meristematic cells in the skin but formed melanized hyphae in brain tissue (48). Fonsecaea multimorphosa, described from a cerebral infection in a cat, presents a cladophialophora-like synasexual state and chlamydospores in culture (49). In addition to these medically relevant species, Fonsecaea includes saprophytic, apparently nonpathogenic taxa, such as F. erecta and F. minima, which occur on plant material (50).

sect2.title: Knufia
sect2.para: Although most species ofKnufia have been described as colonizers of rock and marble, they are occasionally found as colonizers of human skin and nails. Knufia epidermidis (= Coniosporium epidermidis) has been reported from a superficial form of phaeohyphomycosis (51). Species of this genus show a high degree of morphological plasticity and may be able to produce phialides, arthroconidia, holoblastic conidia, endoconidia (conidia produced within an intercalary or terminal “mother cell”), and yeast-like budding elements in culture (52). Knufia epidermidis produces holoblastic conidia, arthroconidia, and meristematic cells in culture (51, 52).

sect2.title: Phialophora
sect2.para: InPhialophora sensu stricto, phialides appear as discrete conidiogenous cells in a poorly developed conidiogenous apparatus or as intercalary cells with lateral openings; they show conspicuous collarettes and produce unicellular, subglobose, tear-shaped, or (sub)cylindrical conidia in slimy masses. Moniliform hyphae and meristematic cells may also be observed. Yeast-like cells and budding conidia are uncommon in Phialophora (53). The genus was phylogenetically heterogeneous because the type species, P. verrucosa, belongs in the family Herpotrichiellaceae, whereas many members of Phialophora sensu lato proved to be related to the genus Cyphellophora, which remained in an uncertain position within Chaetothyriales. Réblová et al. (34) transferred many of those species to Cyphellophora and established the family Cyphellophoraceae. In a recent phylogenetic study, five species were recognized in Phialophora sensu stricto by Li et al. (53). These fungi occur in association with diverse substrates, including plant debris, wood, straw, soil, and coal. In humans, these organisms are associated with different forms of phaeohyphomycosis, chromoblastomycosis, and occasionally mycetoma (2, 53). Phialophora verrucosa, with darkened, funnel-shaped collarettes (Fig. 3g), is one of the best-known species of this genus. Phialophora americana differs mainly by having vase-shaped collarettes (35). Morphologically similar phialidic fungi belonging to other orders are now classified in genera such as Cadophora, Gaeumannomyces, Phaeoacremonium, and Pleurostoma (2, 17, 54).

sect2.title: Rhinocladiella
sect2.para: Rhinocladiella is characterized by melanized sympodial conidiophores bearing noncatenate one-celled conidia on denticles and occasionally shows Exophiala-like budding cells in culture (55). It comprises five pathogenic species, Rhinocladiella aquaspersa (Fig. 3e and f), R. mackenziei (Fig. 3a and b), R. basitona, R. similis, and R. tropicalis, which are polyphyletic within the Chaetothyriales (2, 37, 55). Rhinocladiella atrovirens has been reported to cause cerebral phaeohyphomycosis in an AIDS patient (56), but as this species in a modern, molecular circumscription is limited to isolates growing on conifer wood in northern countries, that case probably concerned the sibling species R. similis (57). Rhinocladiella aquaspersa and R. tropicalis are rare agents of chromoblastomycosis, and the former species may also cause phaeohyphomycosis (37, 58). The neurotropic species R. mackenziei is endemic in the Middle East and is morphologically similar to Pleurothecium obovoideum (formerly Ramichloridium obovoideum). For a long time, these fungi were thought to be conspecific, but phylogenetically they belong in different orders of Ascomycota (P. obovoideum belongs to the Pleurotheciales) (55). Rhinocladiella mackenziei is a BSL-3 agent that deserves special precaution and needs to be handled within a biosafety cabinet (2). Rhinocladiella basitona has been reported from different forms of phaeohyphomycosis in humans (2, 59).

sect2.title: Veronaea
sect2.para: The genusVeronaea includes one clinically relevant taxon, Veronaea botryosa, as well as numerous saprophytes. Veronaea botryosa shows a conidiogenous apparatus similar to that of Rhinocladiella spp., consisting of a melanized, sympodial rachis with denticles. The conidia, however, are 1-septate (1, 2). Numerous cases of phaeohyphomycosis by this agent have been published, mostly involving the skin and subcutaneous tissue. Cases tend to be severe, and many of them are associated with the CARD9 immune disorder (60).

sect2.title: Diaporthe
sect2.para: Diaporthe is a species-rich genus of plant pathogens, endophytes, and saprophytes with widespread geographical distribution (61). At least four members of this genus—Diaporthe bougainvilleicola, D. phaseolorum, D. phoenicicola, and D. longicolla—have been reported from human infections (62–65), but some clinical isolates have been identified only to genus level (66, 67). Reports often used the asexual morph name Phomopsis, but the application of unitary nomenclature has given preference to Diaporthe, the name traditionally used for the sexual state (2, 61). In culture, these fungi may produce pycnidia with two types of conidia, i.e., oval to fusoid “alpha conidia” and thin, curved or bent, elongated “beta conidia” (61). However, intraspecific morphological variability and the inability of some isolates to sporulate in culture often demand the use of DNA sequence data to achieve species-level identifications (65, 68).

sect1.title: Dothideales
sect1.para: The order Dothideales comprises numerous saprophytes that thrive well under conditions of decreased water activity, such as on sugary leaf surfaces, rocks, glass, and moist medical devices (69).

sect2.title: Aureobasidium
sect2.para: The genusAureobasidium contains a number of saprophytic, black yeast-like species associated with diverse substrates, including soil, plant leaves, water, foodstuffs, and oligotrophic environments such as rocks and stone monument surfaces (4, 70). Two members of this genus, i.e., Aureobasidium pullulans and A. melanogenum, are recognized as agents of phaeohyphomycosis in humans, ranging from mild cutaneous infections to invasive, life-threatening disease (71). Aureobasidium spp. are recognized by the production of budding yeast-like elements and of hyaline and thin-walled hyphae, as well as melanized and thick-walled hyphae, with segments becoming dark brown chlamydospores with age. Conidia are produced from both types of hyphae by blastic, synchronous conidiogenous cells. Endoconidia are sometimes also observed. Aureobasidium melanogenum is easily distinguished from A. pullulans by the ability of the former to produce cultures that are characteristically black from the beginning owing to the abundant production of strongly melanized arthroconidia and dark synchronous conidia; in A. pullulans, evident melanization of the colonies usually takes about 2 weeks to develop, and colonies are typically pinkish but may develop radial dark brown areas (4, 70).

sect2.title: Hormonema
sect2.para: One species ofHormonema, Hormonema dematioides, has been reported as an occasional agent of phaeohyphomycosis. This fungus is morphologically similar to Aureobasidium but produces conidia in a basipetal succession with the youngest at the base, not synchronously as in Aureobasidium (2, 4). In addition, DNA sequence-based phylogenies proved that Aureobasidium and Hormonema are different genera (71, 72).

sect1.title: Microascales
sect1.para: Among the clinically relevant genera of Microascales,Lomentospora, Microascus, Scopulariopsis, Scedosporium, and Triadelphia can be mentioned (2). Phylogenetic studies have determined great changes in the nomenclature of most of these genera.

sect2.title: Lomentospora
sect2.para: A single medically relevant species in the genusLomentospora is known, Lomentospora prolificans. This fungus was treated in earlier literature as “Scedosporium prolificans” (= S. inflatum) on account of its elongated annellidic conidiogenous cells and obovoid conidia produced in slimy masses (2). Molecular studies, however, proved that L. prolificans is phylogenetically distant from true Scedosporium species. Phenotypically, the production of more strongly melanized, rather flat colonies, the presence of a swollen basal zone in the conidiogenous cells, and a high resistance to voriconazole separate L. prolificans from true Scedosporium spp. (73).

sect2.title: Microascus
sect2.para: The genusMicroascus was previously considered to represent the sexual state of Scopulariopsis, but multilocus phylogenies proved that the type species of these genera belong in clearly separate clades, supporting their current status as different genera. Species of Microascus are characterized by dark brown to black, globose to ampulliform ascomata, with a papilla or a more or less developed neck; ascospores are one-celled, reniform to ellipsoid, triangular or quadrangular, straw-colored or light brown, with a conspicuous germ pore. The asexual states produce ampulliform to lageniform conidiogenous cells with a narrow cylindrical annellated zone, singly or on penicillate conidiophores; conidia are one-celled, pale yellowish to dark brown, and smooth to finely roughened and appear in dry basipetal chains. Although a broad clinical spectrum has been associated with this genus in the literature, most of the clinical isolates from a recent phylogenetic revision (74) originated from respiratory samples and synovial fluid. Species associated with human infections from that revision include Microascus brunneosporus, M. cinereus, M. gracilis, M. paisii, and other taxa listed in Table 1.

sect2.title: Scopulariopsis
sect2.para: Members of the genusScopulariopsis are characterized by globose to pyriform, black ascomata with an ostiole, and papillate or with a conspicuous neck; ascospores are one-celled, asymmetrical, broadly reniform or lunate, with or without a conspicuous germ pore. The asexual states typically show annellides mostly arranged penicillately on conidiophores but sometimes appearing singly or in small groups on short stalks; conidia are one-celled, hyaline to brown, with a pointed or rounded apex and a truncate base, smooth to rough-walled, and formed in basipetal dry chains (74). This genus includes several clinically relevant taxa, such as Scopulariopsis asperula, S. brevicaulis, and S. candida, implicated mostly in skin and nail infections but occasionally also in deep, more severe disease (2). Species obtained from clinical samples, included in a recent revision (74), are listed in Table 1.

sect2.title: Scedosporium
sect2.para: Scedosporium species are characterized by relatively fast-growing, usually grayish colonies with abundant aerial mycelia and (sub)cylindrical, relatively long conidiophores with annellides; conidia are obovoid and subhyaline but tend to become brown with age. Conidia may also be produced laterally on undifferentiated hyphae or on short pedicels. In addition, a synnematous synasexual state is sometimes observed in culture. Sexual states of Scedosporium traditionally were placed in Pseudallescheria and typically consist of (sub)globose cleistothecia producing one-celled, fusiform to ellipsoid, melanized ascospores (2). When dual nomenclature was still in use, its application caused much confusion with regard to this group of organisms (75, 76). One of the main clinically relevant species, Scedosporium apiospermum, used to be considered the asexual state of Pseudallescheria boydii (2). However, it is currently accepted that P. boydii and Scedosporium apiospermum are two different species, the former homothallic and the latter heterothallic. The separation of these taxa is also supported by molecular data (75, 76). The application of unitary nomenclature led to the choice of Scedosporium as the correct name for this genus, and therefore, certain names in Pseudallescheria needed to be transferred to Scedosporium. Currently, the main Scedosporium species of clinical importance are S. americanum, S. apiospermum, S. aurantiacum, S. boydii, and S. dehoogii, which are associated with various forms of phaeohyphomycosis and occasionally also mycetoma in humans (73, 75–77).

sect2.title: Triadelphia
sect2.para: Triadelphia currently includes 17 species, most of which can produce multiple asexual morphs in culture. Triadelphia is polyphyletic, but many species have not been represented in molecular studies (78). Two species, Triadelphia pulvinata and T. disseminata, have been involved in phaeohyphomycoses in immunocompetent or immunocompromised individuals in Saudi Arabia and Iraq. These species produce three synasexual morphs and can be distinguished by differences in the size and septation of conidia and by their ITS region sequences (79–81).

sect1.title: Ophiostomatales
sect1.para: Ophiostomatales is a large order of plant-pathogenic and saprophytic fungi. Some of them are blue stain fungi in wood and live in association with arthropods. Only a few species are human or animal pathogens. The main sexually typified genus isOphiostoma (82).

sect2.title: Knoxdaviesia
sect2.para: The genusKnoxdaviesia currently includes nine species, characterized by well-developed, brown, simple conidiophores bearing a whorl of phialides at the apex; conidia are (sub)hyaline, aseptate, and cylindrical to allantoid and are produced in slimy masses. One species of Knoxdaviesia has been reported from human infection, Knoxdaviesia dimorphospora, which can easily be distinguished from other members of the genus by its production of a synasexual morph, with phialides appearing mostly laterally on undifferentiated hyphae and ellipsoid, pale brown conidia. The typical robust brown conidiophores generate cylindrical conidia with an obtuse apex and a truncate base (83).

sect2.title: Ophiostoma
sect2.para: Ophiostoma is characterized by the production of subglobose, dark perithecia with evanescent asci and long necks from which hyaline ascospores are extruded in slimy droplets (82). For decades, a close phylogenetic relationship between Ophiostoma and Sporothrix, an important human pathogenic hyphomycete genus, has been recognized (84). Since multilocus phylogenetic studies revealed that clinically relevant Sporothrix species (including the type species, Sporothrix schenckii) belonged to a subclade within a broader Ophiostoma sensu lato clade, one of these genera had to be given priority under unitary nomenclature. Sporothrix is an older genus, but choosing it instead of Ophiostoma would require transferring over 100 species from the latter genus to the former one, including economically important plant pathogens. A choice was made to retain the name Sporothrix for the group containing S. schenckii and related species and to keep Ophiostoma as a separate entity (82). Practically all clinically relevant Ophiostomatales belong to Sporothrix sensu stricto, except Ophiostoma piceae, which caused a fatal invasive infection in an immunocompromised patient. The fungus produced yeast-like cells and septate hyphae in tissue and similar elements in cultures on routine mycological media. Morphological features were not remarkable, but chlamydospore-like cells and cycloheximide tolerance were reported. Species-level identification required DNA sequence analyses (85).

sect2.title: Sporothrix
sect2.para: In natural environments, or in cultures at 25°C,Sporothrix schenckii has colorless hyphae that produce poorly differentiated conidiophores bearing a cluster of thin denticles with hyaline, tear-shaped conidia at their tips. Additional subglobose to elongated, sessile conidia may or may not be present; conidia are the only melanized part of the fungus. The mould can be transformed in vitro to a stable yeast form at 37°C on enriched media such as chocolate agar and brain heart infusion agar. Occasional isolates are difficult to convert and may require multiple subcultures and extended incubation. Transition is observed in environmental as well as clinical isolates (2, 86, 87). The disease caused by this fungus is called sporotrichosis and ranges from localized fixed cutaneous lesions to lymphocutaneous or even disseminated disease, depending largely on the immunological status of the host (88).

Molecular studies have demonstrated thatS. schenckii sensu lato is a complex of numerous phylogenetic species (89). The combination of phenotypic (morphology of the sessile pigmented conidia; growth at 30, 35, and 37°C; and assimilation of sucrose, raffinose, and ribitol) and genetic (analysis of the calmodulin gene sequences and other markers) approaches allows differentiation of some of these species. Apart from S. schenckii sensu stricto, the species S. brasiliensis, S. globosa, and S. luriei are also involved in human sporotrichosis (87, 90). Sporothrix brasiliensis is highly virulent and has caused large epidemics in Brazil; transmission occurs particularly through stray cats (91). Although this species was thought to occur only in Brazil (87), it was recently reported from Argentina (92) and is probably spreading to other regions of South America.

Sporothrix globosa seems to be less aggressive and is mainly prevalent in Asia, where children in particular are infected, but some cases in the Americas also have been reported (93). Sporothrix luriei is a rare species that only has been reported from South Africa, India, and Italy (90). Recently, two additional Sporothrix spp., i.e., S. pallida and S. chilensis, were reported from superficial infections involving human cornea and nails, respectively (94, 95).

sect1.title: Pleosporales
sect1.para: Most members of the order Pleosporales have rapidly expanding, floccose colonies, which show optimal conidium production on media poor in nutrients, such as oatmeal agar and potato carrot agar. Conidia are usually large and easily visible with the aid of a stereomicroscope. Conidia are generally produced on septate, dark brown, erect, sympodial conidiophores with integrated conidiogenous cells showing minute pores (“tretic” conidiogenous cells). Conidia consist of several compartments. “True septa” are found in conidia in which the outer wall and septum are continuous; such conidia are described as “euseptate” (as inAlternaria). “False septa,” in contrast, are observed in conidia in which only the inner wall layers are involved in septation and the outer wall forms a sac-like structure around the individual cells; such conidia are described as “distoseptate” (in Bipolaris, Curvularia, and Exserohilum) (2, 96–98). In addition, several pycnidial members of this group have been reported from clinical samples (99). Their clinical relevance, however, is often uncertain (100).

sect2.title: Alternaria
sect2.para: Since most clinical strains are very likely to belong to only two species complexes ofAlternaria, Alternaria infectoria and A. alternata, isolates are easily identified to the species complex level. Available criteria comprise characteristics of growth, sporulation, and morphology and very large differences in the ITS rDNA and other loci, which can be displayed by sequencing or by restriction fragment length polymorphisms (101, 102). Alternaria infectoria in tissue may present with hyaline yeast-like cells rather than melanized hyphae. Cultures of A. infectoria, in contrast to those of A. alternata, frequently exhibit creamish patches and show reduced sporulation. Conidia of A. infectoria bear long apical beaks that serve as secondary conidiophores. A. alternata displays conidia in chains (2, 97). The genus Ulocladium, associated with occasional cases of phaeohyphomycosis, was revealed by multilocus phylogenies to be synonymous with Alternaria (102). Species traditionally placed in Ulocladium usually show conidiophores that are more geniculate than those of A. infectoria and A. alternata and have more rounded conidia that are in contact with the conidiogenous cells from a narrow conidial base (97, 101, 102).

sect2.title: Bipolaris
sect2.para: Relatively common opportunists traditionally treated inBipolaris include Curvularia (Bipolaris) australiensis, Curvularia (Bipolaris) hawaiiensis (Fig. 4a to c), and Curvularia (Bipolaris) spicifera. They are characterized by large, ellipsoid to subcylindrical, rather straight conidia with conspicuous distosepta and a dark, flat basal scar (2, 103). These species proved to belong to a phylogenetically and morphologically well-characterized group within the genus Curvularia, called the spicifera clade (98). These species are associated with a range of forms of phaeohyphomycosis, especially invasive and noninvasive sinusitis (2, 103). Bipolaris oryzae, a true member of Bipolaris sensu stricto, can cause corneal ulcers in humans (104). This fungus differs from Curvularia sensu stricto by producing long conidia that mostly appear gently curved, show evident distosepta, and lack an asymmetrically swollen, darker intermediate cell (96, 105).

sect2.title: Curvularia
sect2.para: Members of the genusCurvularia usually produce elongated conidia that are inconspicuously distoseptate (the outer and inner conidial wall layers can be seen in young conidia, but both layers usually appear too close together to be distinguished in mature ones with light microscopy) and often possess an intermediate, asymmetrically swollen cell that gives the conidia a typically curved appearance (96, 105). This typical conidial shape is observed in the type species, Curvularia lunata (Fig. 4j), and in several other species of clinical relevance, such as C. aeria, C. americana, C. geniculata, C. hominis, C. muehlenbeckiae, and C. senegalensis (96, 98, 105). Many species that produce conidia with conspicuous distosepta and lack an asymmetrically swollen intermediate cell, however, also cluster in Curvularia, as previously mentioned (105). The clinical spectrum of Curvularia spp. is quite broad, ranging from superficial skin infections and corneal ulcers to mycetoma and invasive phaeohyphomycoses (2, 103).

sect2.title: Exserohilum
sect2.para: Exserohilum is characterized by very long, distoseptate conidia with a distinct, protruding basal hilum (96). Three species have been recognized as opportunistic agents of disease in humans and other vertebrates, i.e., Exserohilum longirostratum, E. mcginnisii, and E. rostratum (Fig. 4k to m) (2, 103). These three species are phylogenetically closely related (106), and a recent study suggested that E. longirostratum and E. mcginnisii might be synonyms of E. rostratum (107). The clinical spectrum of these fungi includes sinusitis, keratitis, endophthalmitis, peritonitis, endocarditis, and other deep-seated forms of phaeohyphomycosis (2, 103).

sect2.title: Gambiomyces
sect2.para: The genusGambiomyces was recently proposed to accommodate a single species, Gambiomyces profunda, a dematiaceous mold isolated from a case of subcutaneous phaeohyphomycosis. The fungus was isolated from skin, joint fluid, and bone of a Gambian patient. In culture, no reproductive structures were observed and, therefore, the identification was based entirely on multilocus sequence data. This species, however, produced chlamydospores and masses of dark brown, tightly interwoven, anastomosing hyphae surrounded by brown, seta-like structures (108). The latter structures probably represented abortive fruiting bodies.

sect2.title: Hongkongmyces
sect2.para: The genusHongkongmyces includes two clinically relevant species, Hongkongmyces pedis and H. snookiorum, which have been reported from cases of subcutaneous phaeohyphomycosis. These fungi do not sporulate on routine mycological media, and their identification requires DNA sequence analyses. Phylogenetic studies proved that these fungi belong in Lindgomycetaceae, a family of Pleosporales that mostly encompasses aquatic fungi (109, 110).

sect2.title: Meanderella
sect2.para: The monotypic genusMeanderella was recently proposed to include a nonsporulating fungus isolated from a case of subcutaneous phaeohyphomycosis in the Netherlands. Multilocus DNA sequence data placed the type species, Meanderella rijsii, in Trematosphaeriaceae, a fungal family encompassing several agents of black-grain mycetoma and wood-inhabiting coelomycetes (111).

sect2.title: Phoma
sect2.para: At least one species inPhoma, Phoma herbarum, is able to cause phaeohyphomycosis in humans. This fungus produces subglobose pycnidia with a conspicuous ostiole, phialidic conidiogenous cells borne directly on the pycnidial wall, and one-celled, ellipsoid to subcylindrical hyaline conidia (2). Phylogenetic studies supported the reallocation of several clinically relevant members of Phoma to separate genera (99, 100, 112).

sect2.title: Pleurophomopsis
sect2.para: The genusPleurophomopsis includes several coelomycetes associated with plant material. One of its members, Pleurophomopsis lignicola, is associated with different forms of phaeohyphomycosis. This fungus is characterized by reddish brown to brown pycnidia which usually show a prominent neck, hyaline, septate conidiophores branched at the base, and phialidic conidiogenous cells giving rise to one-celled, cylindrical, hyaline conidia (113).

sect1.title: Sordariales
sect1.para: Sordariales is a large and diverse order of ascomycetes.Madurella mycetomatis was proven to be a member of Sordariales, belonging in Chaetomiaceae (114); this species is discussed in chapter 129. The genera Phialemonium, Chaetomium, and Achaetomium are addressed in chapter 124. The clinically relevant genus Phialemoniopsis, previously considered as incertae sedis in Sordariomycetes (115), was recently synonymized under Thyridium and placed in the newly created order Thyridiales (116).

Clinical strains producing bulbil-like clumps of strongly melanized cells often have been referred to asPapulaspora spp. They may show a phialidic synasexual morph and do not produce sexual structures in culture. Molecular studies revealed that such “Papulaspora” strains often represent opportunistic members of Sordariales that are phylogenetically distant from the type species of Papulaspora, Papulaspora sepedonioides (Melanosporales) (117).

sect2.title: Podospora
sect2.para: Podospora is a species-rich genus of ascomycetes mainly associated with dung, soil, and plant material (118). It includes one clinically relevant species, Podospora bulbillosa (= Cladorrhinum bulbillosum), which produces intercalary conidiogenous cells with lateral phialidic openings (pleurophialides) and one-celled, subglobose to tear-shaped conidia. This fungus produces abundant microsclerotia in culture and grows rapidly at 37°C or even at 40°C (119–121). Some strains remain sterile and require DNA sequence analysis for identification (122).

sect1.title: Thyridiales
sect1.para: The order Thyridiales was proposed by Sugita and Tanaka (116) to accommodate the monotypic family Thyridiaceae. The type genus, Thyridium, occurs mainly on plants but also has been isolated from soil, polluted water, and various clinical samples (115, 116).

sect2.title: Thyridium
sect2.para: The sexual morphs of this genus are characterized by perithecial ascomata, unitunicate asci, and obovoid or ellipsoid, pale brown to brown, muriform ascospores. In culture, clinically relevant species produce brown or grayish colonies with scarce or absent aerial mycelium. Conidia are produced from simple or branched conidiophores borne solitarily or grouped into sporodochium-like or pycnidium-like, often setose conidiomata. Conidiogenous cells are monophialidic, cylindrical or flask-shaped, and hyaline to brown with collarettes and produce one-celled, ellipsoidal, allantoid or obovoid, hyaline to subhyaline, smooth-walled conidia with a slightly apiculate base (115, 116).

sect2.title: Phaeoacremonium
sect2.para: Phaeoacremonium is morphologically characterized by warted mycelium and slender, tubular, and often tapering or inflated brown phialides. Hyaline, slimy conidia are produced through inconspicuous collarettes. The sexual state was named Togninia and is characterized by perithecia with long necks and paraphyses and by 8-spored asci with hyaline, aseptate, ellipsoid to allantoid ascospores. Following unitary nomenclature, the name Phaeoacremonium was chosen for usage instead of the latter (123). Eleven species are associated with human disease (Table 1), Phaeoacremonium parasiticum (Fig. 2j) being one of the most common.

sect2.title: Verruconis and Scolecobasidium
sect2.para: Scolecobasidium and Verruconis are morphologically similar genera in the family Sympoventuriaceae (124). Members of these genera have rust brown to olivaceous colonies and produce 1- to 3-septate conidia from small, open denticles inserted in low numbers on sympodial, melanized conidiophores. Conidial secession occurs rhexolytically in both genera, but phylogenetic analyses and phenotypic features can distinguish them. While Verruconis species are thermophilic and produce strongly verrucose conidia, Scolecobasidium spp. are mesophilic and show smooth to verruculose conidia (2, 125). The main clinically relevant species in this complex is the neurotropic fungus Verruconis gallopava, characterized by hyaline, clavate, strongly ornamented conidia and its ability to growth at 40°C. Scolecobasidium musae (= Ochroconis mirabilis) and other species of this genus have rarely been associated with human disease (126).

sect1.title: Phaeohyphomycosis
sect1.para: Phaeohyphomycoses are usually subcutaneous but can also be systemic or involve the central nervous system (127). Dematiaceous fungi are also able to cause superficial infections, such as those of the skin and nails (29, 71, 128). Infections of the central nervous system (CNS) are frequently manifested as brain abscesses or meningitis, which are usually fatal. In these infections, fungi can be present in the cerebrospinal fluid. Many cases occur in immunocompetent patients. Typical symptoms include headache, neurologic deficits, and seizures. Common neurotropic species are Cladophialophora bantiana, Ramichloridium mackenziei, Verruconis gallopava, and Exophiala dermatitidis (2, 127). The fungus probably disseminates from a primary pulmonary focus to the CNS, but other routes are possible, including dissemination from skin or subcutaneous lesions (48, 49, 129). The fungi most commonly involved in phaeohyphomycosis are Exophiala xenobiotica, E. jeanselmei, E. dermatitidis, E. spinifera, Cladophialophora bantiana, and Curvularia spp. Superficial infections are mostly caused by Alternaria spp., Neoscytalidium dimidiatum, and black yeast-like species such as Exophiala oligosperma, Cyphellophora europaea, and Hortaea werneckii (33, 128–130).

The route of (sub)cutaneous infection and keratitis is likely to be traumatic implantation, with the fungus causing an inflammatory reaction with pigmented hyphae and sometimes also yeast-like elements in tissue (127). In tinea nigra, by contrast, the etiological agent, Hortaea werneckii, probably finds on the surface of human skin conditions of humidity, pH, salinity, etc. which are not too different from those of its natural habitats, favoring colonization of the stratum corneum (2, 18). Chromoblastomycosis leads to excessive proliferation of skin layers, with muriform cells being the invasive form. The development of either phaeohyphomycosis or chromoblastomycosis in black yeast-like chaetothyrialean fungi is largely species specific, although certain etiological agents, e.g., Phialophora macrospora and Fonsecaea monophora, may cause both types of infection (2, 53).

The species that cause subcutaneous infections are often uncommon in the environment and occupy hitherto poorly known habitats. Some thermotolerant species seem to be associated with environmental xenobiotics or occur in animal feces (42, 131); others are found on slightly osmotic surfaces, such as fruit (4). Psychrophilic species that cause infections in cold-blooded vertebrates are frequent in water of lakes and oceans, municipal drinking water, hospital water, and river sediments (22, 132–134). In the indoor environment, Exophiala has been found in steam baths (135) and dishwashers (136). Members of the Pleosporales such as Alternaria, Bipolaris, Curvularia, and Exserohilum cause disease in numerous plant hosts but also occur as saprophytes on decaying plant material and in soil (96, 97). They may be encountered in allergic or invasive sinusitis of human and cattle, in lesions of the skin and subcutaneous tissue, in onychomycosis, keratomycosis, and other infections (2, 98, 101–107, 130). Many members of the Dothideales are tolerant of extreme growth conditions and are found in Antarctic or Mediterranean rock (137) or in hypersaline ponds (69). These species can transition morphologically to a stress-tolerant, meristematic ecotype consisting of clumps of amorphous, thick-walled, highly melanized cells that may eventually fall apart into small cell clumps (2). Most clinically relevant Botryosphaeriales, Diaporthales, and Togniniales included in this chapter are plant pathogens (12, 61, 123), whereas the Microascales, Sordariales, and Venturiales mentioned here are mostly soilborne saprophytes, degraders of cellulose-rich substrates, and endophytes (73–79, 117–122, 125, 126).

sect1.title: Chromoblastomycosis
sect1.para: Chromoblastomycosis is one of the most frequently found subcutaneous mycoses. It usually occurs in tropical and subtropical regions, affecting mainly adult males working in agriculture or related activities (2, 138). The fact that males are predominantly affected has been related to a possible role of human sex hormones, but probably occupational factors also favor exposure to the etiological agents (139, 140). The fungus usually penetrates the cutaneous barrier through puncture wounds, usually caused by a thorn or a splinter (138). The fungal agents causing these infections are occasionally found on rotting plant material and in soil (2, 53). Several reports have associated some of these fungi with palm trees and xerophyte plants, but recent sequencing data have proven that mostly other, strictly saprophytic relatives are concerned (50). For example, in dry areas of Venezuela, cactus plant thorns carry Cladophialophora yegresii, while human cases are caused by C. carrionii. Cladophialophora yegresii produces muriform cells in the spines morphologically similar to those known as the invasive form of C. carrionii in chromoblastomycosis. These cells may thus be regarded as an extremotolerant survival phase and are likely to play an essential role in the natural life cycle of these organisms (2, 31). The ecology of the fungi causing chromoblastomycosis is still incompletely understood. Fonsecaea species are isolated in the evergreen forests of tropical areas, whereas C. carrionii is identified only in desert areas under arid climatic conditions (138, 140).

sect1.title: Sporotrichosis
sect1.para: PathogenicSporothrix species can be found in soil and thorny plants. Infection is mostly acquired through traumatic inoculation (2). Cases of primary pulmonary sporotrichosis are acquired by inhalation and commonly affect individuals with a history of alcohol abuse (141). Sporothrix brasiliensis, however, is frequently transmitted from bites or scratches from stray cats, which are considered a primary host of this fungus (92). Occasional outbreaks occur in different populations, such as gardeners, rural workers, armadillo hunters, and persons in contact with domestic cats (2). In Brazil, a large epidemic occurred because of expansion of S. brasiliensis (91). In the United States, several outbreaks of sporotrichosis, associated with occupational or recreational exposure to sphagnum moss, have been reported; the largest occurred in 1988 and involved 84 patients (88). Most infections occur in otherwise healthy individuals, but Sporothrix infections have also been recognized as opportunistic in immunocompromised individuals (142).

sect2.title: CLINICAL SIGNIFICANCE
sect2.para: Disorders caused by the fungi described in this chapter are mainly localized and may occur in otherwise healthy hosts. The infections arise mostly after traumatic inoculation of contaminated material from the environment; less frequently, e.g., in the case of sinusitis, otitis, or growth in the mucus of lungs of patients with cystic fibrosis, asymptomatic or mostly mildly symptomatic colonization of cavities is observed (2, 103, 127). A number of the fungi discussed in this chapter are typical opportunists, causing infections increasing in severity in individuals with impaired innate immunity and metabolic diseases such as diabetes (81, 127, 143). Such patients may have cutaneous infections by black yeasts that are otherwise found on cold-blooded animals (134), but the clinical course of such infections is usually mild (144–146). Infections also arise in patients with severe immunological disorders, neutropenic patients, solid-organ transplant recipients, and patients undergoing long-term corticosteroid therapy (127, 130). This is particularly noted with Scedosporium species and L. prolificans (73, 75–77). Some species of Chaetothyriales (such as Cladophialophora bantiana and Rhinocladiella mackenziei) can cause deep or disseminated infections in hosts with no known immunosuppression. If untreated, such infections may take a chronic, fatal course after a destructive disease process (2, 143). The frequency of these infections is low, but given the potentially severe course of the disease, as well as the sometimes very high degrees of resistance to antifungal drugs, attentiveness to these fungi is mandatory. Chromoblastomycosis is a relatively frequent infection with significant morbidity in rural subtropical regions (138). Sporothrix infections increase in severity with defects of acquired cellular immunity, such as AIDS and iatrogenic immunosuppression (88, 142).
Among the specific disease entities caused by the melanized fungi are the following.

sect3.title: Botryosphaeriales
sect3.para: Neoscytalidium dimidiatum is a common plant pathogen in the tropics and is regularly involved in syndromes very similar to dermatophytosis on skin and nails, usually leading to extensive hyperkeratosis (128). Neoscytalidium novaehollandiae and Lasiodiplodia theobromae were recently reported as etiological agents of onychomycosis (147, 148).

sect3.title: Capnodiales
sect3.para: The halophilic speciesHortaea werneckii can adhere to human skin, especially on the palms and soles, where superficial growth of the fungus leads to the formation of hyperpigmented maculae, causing a syndrome in the dead keratin layers known as tinea nigra (2, 18).

sect3.title: Chaetothyriales
sect3.para: Some species of the order Chaetothyriales cause occasional superficial infections in humans.Cladophialophora boppii has been reported from a case of onychomycosis (145), and Cladophialophora saturnica was reported from a tinea nigra-like infection in an HIV-positive patient (29). Cyphellophora laciniata and C. pluriseptata are occasionally isolated from human skin and nails (33), but their etiology has not unambiguously been proven. Cyphellophora europaea and various Exophiala spp. are involved in skin and nail infections, but because of their slow growth, they might be frequently overlooked (33, 144–146).

sect3.title: Dothideales
sect3.para: A rare tinea nigra-like infection of the facial skin caused byAureobasidium melanogenum in an otherwise healthy patient was reported (71).

sect3.title: Microascales
sect3.para: Species ofScopulariopsis are frequently isolated from human skin and nails, often from asymptomatic individuals. However, several species, such as the common opportunist S. brevicaulis, can cause infection in keratinized tissues (2, 74). Triadelphia pulvinata was reported from eczematoid, scaly lesions in the eyelids of an otherwise healthy patient (79). Infections by this fungus have been reported only from Saudi Arabia and Iraq.

sect3.title: Ophiostomatales
sect3.para: The recently described speciesSporothrix chilensis is a soilborne fungus that may infect human nails (95).

sect3.title: Pleosporales
sect3.para: Alternaria alternata and Curvularia spp. are occasionally reported as agents of opportunistic onychomycosis, usually in patients with a history of ungual trauma, exposure to soil, or immunosuppression (130, 149).

sect3.title: Botryosphaeriales
sect3.para: Lasiodiplodia theobromae is occasionally found to cause ocular infections following injury to the cornea (8). Cases of posttraumatic keratitis also have been attributed to Macrophomina phaseolina (150), Neoscytalidium dimidiatum (151), and Neoscytalidium oculi (14). A case of cutaneous infection caused by M. phaseolina in a child with acute myeloid leukemia was published by Srinivasan et al. (11).

sect3.title: Cladosporiales
sect3.para: Species ofCladosporium, such as C. cladosporioides and C. oxysporum, are associated with allergic disease in the indoor environment, with numerous (sub)cutaneous and even deep infections, but there remains some doubt about their pathogenic role. Considering that Cladosporium spp. are extremely common laboratory contaminants, it would be prudent to corroborate the identity of any potential Cladosporium opportunist by in situ hybridization or immunohistochemistry (2, 3).

sect3.title: Chaetothyriales
sect3.para: Cladophialophora emmonsii, C. boppii, and C. saturnica are rare agents of mild cutaneous infections (2, 28, 29); also, several Exophiala and Phialophora species may cause skin infections with various degrees of severity (42, 53, 57, 129, 146). Knufia epidermidis so far has been found almost exclusively on human skin. The species may cause asymptomatic colonization, may be found in association with dermatophyte infections, or may cause mild cutaneous infections. The infection by this agent superficially resembles tinea nigra, but fungal elements of K. epidermidis may invade deeper layers of the skin, even reaching the basal membrane of the dermis (51), while in tinea nigra, only the stratum corneum is involved (2). Certain Exophiala spp., such as E. dermatitidis and E. jeanselmei, are rare agents of keratitis, usually after traumas or surgery (152, 153).

sect3.title: Diaporthales
sect3.para: Diaporthe phoenicicola was reported from a case of scleral keratitis after pterygium surgery (62). Diaporthe longicolla and D. phaseolorum have caused cutaneous lesions in transplant patients (63, 65).

sect3.title: Ophiostomatales
sect3.para: Sporothrix pallida, an environmental fungus mostly isolated from soil, has been reported as an etiological agent of keratitis in a corneal transplant recipient (94).

sect3.title: Pleosporales
sect3.para: One of the main recognized clinical entities associated with Pleosporales is cutaneous infection in immunosuppressed patients caused byAlternaria and mainly affecting patients on long-term steroid use, tacrolimus, or other immunosuppressive agents. Most cases have been attributed to Alternaria infectoria and A. alternata, two common saprophytic species of the genus (101), and certain infections attributed to A. chlamydospora probably concerned meristematic strains of A. alternata (130). Cutaneous infections also have been attributed to A. tenuissima (101) and to the recently proposed species A. anthropophila, A. atrobrunnea, and A. guarroi (154). Exserohilum rostratum and several Curvularia spp., such as Curvularia (Bipolaris) spicifera, C. lunata, and C. senegalensis, can occasionally cause infections of the skin and cornea (2, 98, 103). Bipolaris oryzae also has been reported from keratitis (104).

sect3.title: Sordariales
sect3.para: Podospora bulbillosa is an agent of fungal keratitis. Three cases have been reported so far, and two of them followed local traumas. Human cases were reported by Zapater and Scattini (119) and Gajjar et al. (122); one case in a horse was reported by Chopin et al. (120). Several cases of corneal infections in a horse and humans have been attributed to Papulaspora equi (155, 156). BLAST searches, surprisingly, show that the ITS sequence of the ex-type strain of P. equi, CBS 573.89 (GenBank accession number JX280870), is 99% similar to that of the ex-type strain of Podospora bulbillosa, CBS 304.90 (GenBank number FM955448). These results indicate that P. equi and P. bulbillosa are probably synonyms. If these names are synonyms, the correct name for the fungus is P. bulbillosa, since P. equi is phylogenetically distant from the type species of Papulaspora, P. sepedonioides (117, 118). Papulaspora equi probably represents strains of P. bulbillosa which are unable to produce phialides in culture but only show microsclerotia, as described by Gajjar et al. (122). Other strains of “Papulaspora” isolated from corneal infections in humans recently proved to be phylogenetically related to the ascomycete genus Subramaniula (117).

sect3.title: Thyridiales
sect3.para: Thyridium cornearis, T. curvatum, and T. oculorum have been associated with corneal infections in humans (115).

sect3.title: Botryosphaeriales
sect3.para: Rare cases of subcutaneous infection byLasiodiplodia theobromae (7) and Neoscytalidium dimidiatum (157) have been reported. A subcutaneous granuloma in a cat was attributed to Macrophomina sp., but it is difficult to speculate about the identity of the etiological agent from the brief description and images in the clinical report (158).

sect3.title: Calosphaeriales
sect3.para: Human infections byPleurostoma richardsiae mostly involve subcutaneous cysts and abscesses, occasionally with bone involvement. Most patients have some underlying condition such as diabetes or transplantation (159). A case of yellow-grain mycetoma was caused by P. ochraceum (16).

sect3.title: Chaetothyriales
sect3.para: Over 10Exophiala spp. have been associated with subcutaneous lesions in humans (2, 4, 40, 41, 129, 134). Exophiala dermatitidis is the most commonly encountered Exophiala species in clinical settings, causing infections of cutaneous and subcutaneous tissues mostly in immunocompromised patients (2, 160). Exophiala oligosperma is a common etiologic agent of subcutaneous infections in immunosuppressed, elderly, diabetic, or otherwise debilitated individuals (161). Exophiala jeanselmei is considered mainly an agent of subcutaneous infections, including mycetoma, often in otherwise healthy individuals (42, 162). Cladophialophora bantiana and C. mycetomatis are also agents of mycetoma (2, 28, 127). Uncommon agents of subcutaneous phaeohyphomycosis in vertebrates include Cladophialophora devriesii, C. immunda (2, 28), Cyphellophora suttonii (36), and Veronaea botryosa (60). A case of olecranon bursitis attributed to Anthopsis deltoidea (24) was probably caused by an undescribed Anthopsis species (25). Phaeoannellomyces elegans was reported from a case of subcutaneous cyst in a farm worker (44).

Cyphellophora suttonii was isolated from ulcerative lesions in the leg of a patient undergoing prednisone treatment for sarcoidosis. The patient previously had developed infections with Cryptococcus neoformans and Exophiala dermatitidis (38). A subcutaneous infection by C. suttonii in a dog was reported by Ajello et al. (36). The reservoir of this uncommon fungus appears to be soil (23).

sect3.title: Diaporthales
sect3.para: Diaporthe bougainvilleicola caused prepatellar bursitis in a renal transplant patient (64), and a Diaporthe sp. produced an abscess and osteomyelitis in a finger of a patient with diabetes and rheumatoid arthritis undergoing prednisone treatment (66). A case of mycetoma with yellowish grains was caused by Diaporthe phaseolorum (68).

sect3.title: Microascales
sect3.para: Several species ofScedosporium are common causes of subcutaneous infections and mycetoma in temperate regions, having a predilection for the joints (77, 163). Lomentospora prolificans, Microascus spp., and Scopulariopsis spp. are associated with diverse clinical manifestations, including subcutaneous infections (2, 73–75, 164).

sect3.title: Ophiostomatales
sect3.para: Knoxdaviesia dimorphospora was reported from a case of olecranon bursitis (83).

sect3.title: Pleosporales
sect3.para: Members of the order Pleosporales (most commonlyAlternaria, Curvularia, and Exserohilum) are able to cause subcutaneous infections, although they more commonly produce sinusitis with occasional cerebral involvement in otherwise healthy individuals (2, 103, 127, 130). A number of pycnidial pleosporalean species are implicated in subcutaneous phaeohyphomycosis, and some of them also occur as etiological agents of mycetoma (99, 100, 112, 113). Certain agents in this order lack sporulation on routine mycological media, i.e. Gambiomyces profunda, Hongkongmyces pedis, Hongkongmyces snookiorum, and Meanderella rijsii. These fungi, therefore, can be identified only using DNA sequence data (108–111).

sect3.title: Thyridiales
sect3.para: Thyridium oculorum and T. hongkongense have been associated with subcutaneous infections in humans. Thyridium pluriloculosum has been isolated from human synovial fluid (2, 115, 116).

sect3.title: Togniniales
sect3.para: Members of the order Togniniales are typical agents of subcutaneous infections. Most of the 11 pathogenic species ofPhaeoacremonium cause this type of infection, including cases of mycetoma and various forms of superficial and invasive phaeohyphomycosis. In addition, the genus includes numerous important plant pathogens (123).

sect3.title: Venturiales
sect3.para: Although infections byVerruconis gallopava usually affect the central nervous system and lungs, this pathogen also causes cutaneous and subcutaneous phaeohyphomycosis (165). Scolecobasidium musae and S. tshawytschae occasionally cause subcutaneous infections in humans and other vertebrates (166, 167).

sect3.title: Botryosphaeriales
sect3.para: Lasiodiplodia theobromae has been involved in a case of pneumonia (168). Neoscytalidium dimidiatum caused deep infections in immunocompromised patients, including fungemia and abdominal abscesses, and disseminated infection with skin and bone involvement in a renal transplant patient (157, 169).

sect3.title: Chaetothyriales
sect3.para: A disease entity that is caused almost exclusively by chaetothyrialean fungi is phaeohyphomycotic brain abscess (2). It affects both immunocompetent and immunocompromised individuals, and the first symptoms of disease are of a neurologic nature (2, 127). Hyphal elements that show melanization either directly or after Fontana-Masson staining are observed in abscesses in the brain parenchyma. The portal of entry may be the lung, but frequently symptoms are confined to the brain. The main etiological agent is Cladophialophora bantiana, and at least one-third of the cases by this pathogen involve otherwise healthy individuals (143). If untreated, the infections are fatal within 1 to 6 months. Exophiala dermatitidis is responsible for a striking number of fatal, neurotropic infections in young, healthy individuals, all in Asia (143, 160, 161). Other less frequent etiological agents are Cladophialophora modesta, Fonsecaea monophora, F. pugnacius, and Rhinocladiella mackenziei (2). Rhinocladiella mackenziei is a remarkable fungus because it is exclusively known from fatal brain infections in the Middle East or from emigrants from that region (2, 143). Several patients had no known immune deficiency; the environmental niche of the species is unknown. Occasionally, systemic dissemination is observed in patients with or without proven predisposing factors; these infections are fatal if they go untreated. Secondary cutaneous lesions often lead to marked eruptions with high morbidity. The disorder has been observed repeatedly with Cladophialophora devriesii, C. modesta, C. arxii, Exophiala dermatitidis, and E. spinifera (2, 143, 160, 170, 171). The last two species have capsule-like extracellular polysaccharides around yeast cells and have a high degree of virulence in humans (172). The rare infections by E. spinifera can be localized, but in about one-half of the cases, fatal, disseminated mycoses are observed in adolescents (reviewed by Kondori et al. [173]). Exophiala dermatitidis and, to a lesser extent, E. phaeomuriformis are regular pulmonary colonizers of patients with cystic fibrosis (173). Exophiala asiatica was reported from a case of disseminated infection in an immunocompetent patient (174).

The etiologic agents in cases of cerebral phaeohyphomycosis published under the nameFonsecaea pedrosoi should be reconsidered, since other, more recently described etiological agents, such as F. monophora, F. pugnacius, and F. multimorphosa, are able to cause infection and exhibit neurotropism (2, 46, 143). Occasionally, opportunistic infections including endocarditis and osteomyelitis caused by Phialophora verrucosa have been reported (175, 176). It is possible that some of these infections were attributable to a different, morphologically similar Phialophora species (53). Arthrocladium fulminans was reported from a case of fatal disseminated disease in an immunocompromised patient (26) and from a case of arthritis and osteomyelitis in an otherwise healthy individual (27).

sect3.title: Dothideales
sect3.para: Aureobasidium pullulans has been implicated as an agent of catheter-related septicemia, peritonitis, and disseminated infection (2, 70, 177), and Hormonema dematioides has been implicated in a case of cutaneous lesions, fungemia, and peritonitis (2, 178).

sect3.title: Microascales
sect3.para: Relatively common deep and disseminated infections caused byScedosporium have been noted for immunosuppressed or otherwise healthy patients (2, 127). The reported clinical spectrum of this genus has changed over time, from prevalently chronic mycetoma in otherwise healthy patients between 1911 and 1980 to systemic opportunistic infection after 1980. Systemic infections after solid-organ transplantation are relatively frequent. Osteomyelitis and arthritis are also relatively common (179). Fisher et al. (180) were the first to describe an association of S. apiospermum with near-drowning syndrome, which characteristically leads to delayed, potentially fatal brain infection after the patient has recovered from the primary effects of aspiration of polluted water. In severely compromised patients, cerebral dissemination may take place from local foci (2, 179). Scedosporium species show a high incidence in cystic fibrosis patients but occur mostly as colonizers in this population (73, 75, 179).

Despite its rather frequent occurrence in clinical settings, the history ofLomentospora prolificans, one of the most virulent species of Microascales, is remarkably short (73). Malloch and Salkin described the first clinical cases in 1984 (181). Since then, numerous strains have been recovered, mostly from clinical cases with major immunosuppression, and since no older reports of cases in immunocompetent patients are known, the species is a truly emerging opportunist (182). The species has been reported from bone and soft tissue infections as well as from (secondary) cutaneous infection, fungemia, and endocarditis. The fungus may disseminate to visceral organs in immunocompromised individuals (179, 181, 182). A nosocomial outbreak has been described (183).
Triadelphia disseminata and Triadelphia pulvinata have caused disseminated infections in patients with acute myeloid leukemia and diabetes, respectively (5, 80, 81).

sect3.title: Ophiostomatales
sect3.para: Ophiostoma piceae caused a fatal invasive infection involving the lungs and brain in a patient with acute lymphoblastic leukemia. This fungus showed both elongated yeast-like elements and septate hyphae in tissue and in culture. Colonies were poorly pigmented at first but became dark with age. Microscopical examination did not show sporothrix-like sympodial conidiophores (85).

sect3.title: Pleosporales
sect3.para: A wide spectrum of invasive opportunistic infections has been attributed toCurvularia, including endocarditis, pulmonary infection, cerebral infection, and peritonitis (98, 105, 184, 185). Exserohilum rostratum caused a large iatrogenic outbreak after injection with contaminated methylprednisolone preparations, leading to numerous fatal cases of meningitis and CNS vasculitis (186).

sect3.title: Togniniales
sect3.para: Phaeoacremonium parasiticum is able to cause deep or disseminated infections in debilitated patients (123, 187).

sect3.title: Venturiales
sect3.para: Verruconis gallopava causes epizootic encephalitis in flocks of turkeys and chickens and can also cause pulmonary or invasive infections in immunocompetent and immunocompromised individuals (125–127).

sect1.title: Chromoblastomycosis
sect1.para: Chromoblastomycosis occurs in otherwise healthy patients; it is characterized by chronic, cutaneous to subcutaneous lesions and frequently with marked hyperplasia. A primary lesion is represented by a papula at the site of inoculation that slowly enlarges over time, becoming a plaque or a tumoral (cauliflower-like) lesion that can spread via the lymphatic system, although hematogenous dissemination has also been proposed. Lesions contain the typical and resistant subspherical and mostly cruciately septate muriform (sclerotic) bodies, indicative of chromoblastomycosis (138).

A few species of Chaetothyriales account for most cases of chromoblastomycosis:Cladophialophora carrionii, Fonsecaea pedrosoi, and Phialophora verrucosa. Infections by C. carrionii mainly occur in arid climates, probably acquired via traumatic inoculation of cactus spines (31). Occasionally, Cladophialophora boppii (188) and, more recently, Cladophialophora samoënsis, Cyphellophora ludoviensis, Fonsecaea monophora, F. nubica, and Rhinocladiella tropicalis have also been reported as causes of chromoblastomycosis (2, 28, 37, 47). Infections by P. verrucosa mainly occur in tropical climatic zones (189). Rhinocladiella aquaspersa is a rare agent of chromoblastomycosis in Latin America (58). Systemic dissemination is very rare; a recent case caused by Fonsecaea pugnacius showed verrucous lesions in the right arm and face that developed over decades and contained typical muriform bodies. The infection disseminated later to the brain, where the fungus produced a phaeohyphomycotic mycelial phase (48).

sect1.title: Sporotrichosis
sect1.para: Sporotrichosis is a cutaneous to subcutaneous chronic infection that can undergo lymphatic spread. Musculoskeletal involvement and disseminated infection are relatively rare, as are the nasal and pulmonary infections that may arise from inhalation of conidia (141). Most infections originate from traumatic implantation of the fungus (2, 88). Some disseminated cases were observed in immunocompromised patients (142). In addition, infections have been described as being transmitted by animals (91, 190).

sect2.title: COLLECTION, TRANSPORT, AND STORAGE OF SPECIMENS
sect2.para: Collection, transport, and storage of specimens are described inchapter 118. Appropriate collection of specimens is essential for mycological study. There should be sufficient quantity for direct microscopic examination as well as for isolation.

sect1.title: Microscopy
sect1.para: Melanization of vegetative cells or conidia, which results in colony coloration ranging from olive, gray, or light brown to black, is caused by the deposition of dihydroxynaphthalene melanin in cell walls. This property occurs commonly among species classified in very different parts of the fungal kingdom (2, 127). The amount of melanin expressed in host tissue may be very small and difficult to observe with traditional histologic stains. The use of the Fontana-Masson stain (see chapter 119) for demonstrating the presence of melanin is therefore recommended as a routine step to facilitate the detection of fungi with melanized hyphae. However, negative or focally positive results may be obtained in samples from infections caused by dematiaceous fungi, but fungal structures often show a remarkable morphological variability, with irregular or moniliform hyphae and/or yeast-like elements. Sporothrix and Scedosporium usually have hyaline mycelia but are able to produce melanized conidia (2). Sporothrix has a characteristic cigar-shaped yeast form in tissue (88); the recognition of Scedosporium relies on methods other than histopathology.

There are numerous procedures for treating specimens to enhance fungal detection, including treatment with potassium hydroxide or calcofluor white and Giemsa, Wright, or Gram stain (seechapter 119). Histopathology procedures using periodic acid-Schiff (PAS), hematoxylin and eosin, or methenamine silver enhance observation. Fontana-Masson staining is useful to detect melanization in cells that appear hyaline with light microscopy (191). To summarize, some characteristic features include the following.

sect2.title: Skin Infections
sect2.para: Pigmented hyphal fragments and, occasionally, melanized yeast-like cells are visible in infected skin tissue (Fig. 5). Certain agents of phaeohyphomycosis may produce brown, thick-walled chlamydospore-like cells in vivo, which could be misinterpreted as sclerotic bodies of chromoblastomycosis (192).
