sect2.title: Sinusitis
sect2.para: In sinusitis, the sinuses are often occluded by amorphous fungus balls. Histologic examination reveals the presence of dense masses of pigmented, branched, and septate hyphae usually not invading the mucosa (127). Invasion of the mucosa mostly occurs in immunosuppressed individuals (9, 130).

sect2.title: Cerebral Infection
sect2.para: In cases of cerebral infection, the hyphae are often poorly colored and scantily branched. In advanced cases, abscesses are formed (130, 143, 179, 180) (Fig. 5).

sect2.title: Disseminated Infection
sect2.para: Pigmented or poorly colored fungal elements such as hyphae or yeast-like cells can be observed in cases of disseminated infection (169, 174) (Fig. 6).

sect2.title: Chromoblastomycosis
sect2.para: The hallmark of chromoblastomycosis is the presence of muriform or sclerotic cells in tissue sections or wet preparations of pus, scrapings, or biopsy samples (2, 138). Muriform cells are swollen, spherical, dark brown, thick-walled cells that often develop a septum and may finally become divided by intersecting septa in more than one plane (Fig. 6).

sect2.title: Sporotrichosis
sect2.para: In sporotrichosis, hyaline, often cigar-shaped yeast cells are present, bearing slender daughter cells at very narrow bases. They are usually few and may easily be missed during microscopy (2, 88), so Gomori methenamine silver (GMS) or PAS staining is therefore recommended; Fontana-Masson staining is negative (Fig. 6). Scarce yeast cells were also observed in a case of onychomycosis associated with Sporothrix chilensis (95, 193). In infections caused by S. luriei, large, thick-walled elements with one septum can be observed in addition to yeast cells (90). Interestingly, in a corneal ulcer caused by S. pallida, the fungus appeared as hyaline hyphae in the infected tissue (94).

sect1.title: Antigen and Nucleic Acid Detection
sect1.para: There are few data for detection of antigens or nucleic acids in human clinical samples for diagnosis of the mycoses included in this chapter. The detection of (1→3)-β-D-glucan (BG), a fungal cell wall component, in serum and sterile body fluids is a useful marker of invasive fungal infections. The value of BG as a diagnostic adjunct has been proven in several studies about candidiasis and aspergillosis. However, patients with invasive infections by less common pathogens, such as species of Alternaria, Cladosporium, and Scedosporium, also have shown BG reactivity in serum (194). BG also showed high sensitivity and specificity for diagnosis of fungal meningitis caused by Exserohilum rostratum during an iatrogenic outbreak in the United States associated with contaminated steroid injections (195). In that study, BG levels correlated with clinical response, representing useful adjunctive data for the clinical management of patients.

sect1.para: A panfungal PCR assay has been developed that targets the ITS1 region of the rDNA gene cluster to detect fungal DNA in fresh and paraffin-embedded tissue specimens. This method was useful for identifying species ofScedosporium, Exophiala, and Exserohilum. PCR products were sequenced and compared with sequences in the GenBank database (196). Linked to the recent outbreak of Exserohilum rostratum infections due to injections of contaminated steroids in United States, several molecular tests were developed for rapid identification of the fungus. Gade et al. (197) developed a test based on the detection of free-circulating fungal DNA from human fluids and subsequent PCR amplification, using panfungal and Exserohilum-specific primers that target the ITS2 region, and sequencing. This test proved to be more sensitive than cultures. A very sensitive Exserohilum rostratum-specific real-time PCR for rapid detection and quantification of the fungus in cerebrospinal fluid or brain tissues of patients with meningitis has also been developed (198).

sect2.title: ISOLATION PROCEDURES
sect2.para: Clinically relevant dematiaceous fungi grow well on standard mycological media, such as Sabouraud dextrose agar. This medium is adequate for isolation; however, it may be too rich in simple nutrients to stimulate sporulation properly, as it generally favors growth of vegetative hyphae instead of reproductive structures. The use of nutritionally poor media, such as cornmeal agar, potato carrot agar, oatmeal agar, or 2% water agar with moistened sterile wooden sticks, sterilized leaves, or moistened sterile filter paper, stimulates the formation of reproductive structures. Once isolation has been achieved, if no sporulation is obtained, these nutrient-poor media are highly recommended (2, 112). In the case of infection due to more than one agent, the strain that grows in a more limited manner may pass unnoticed for a long period. Therefore, a loopful of cells suspended in 0.1% Tween and streaked onto a fresh culture plate is useful to select an individual colony for identification.

For primary isolation, use of culture media with and without cycloheximide is recommended. This inhibitory substance is tolerated by many important dematiaceous pathogens, including members of the Chaetothyriales and Ophiostomatales, but numerous species in other taxonomic groups are sensitive (2, 22, 85).

sect2.title: IDENTIFICATION
sect2.para: For the identification of most of the species included in this chapter, the classical method is to grow the fungi in culture and to examine the relevant morphological characteristics described above. This method will mostly provide identification at the generic level. Further information on appropriate culture media is provided inchapter 119. Slide culture preparations using potato dextrose agar or cornmeal dextrose agar, which should be handled only within a biological safety cabinet, are ideal for determining conidiogenesis. For morphological features of most of the fungi treated in this chapter, see the work of de Hoog et al. (2).

Molecular identification of most species is currently performed by sequencing of ribosomal genes and comparison with dedicated databases (199), such as those provided by the Westerdijk Fungal Biodiversity Institute (Utrecht, Netherlands; www.mycobank.org) and the International Society for Human and Animal Mycology (http://its.mycologylab.org/). Care should be taken when the GenBank database is used for identification of less known fungal groups, because over 10% of the sequences may be incorrect (101). Therefore, sequences should be evaluated not only from a technical point of view but also nomenclaturally. Currently, GenBank explicitly highlights sequences obtained from type material or ex-type strains, and comparisons made with BLAST can be restricted to such taxonomically reliable sequences (200).

When ribosomal genes are used, the phylogenetic position of taxa, at least at the genus level, can be established by sequencing the nuclear SSU (18S) or partial large-subunit (28S) rRNA gene. These genes are mostly invariant between closely related species. In most fungal groups, species diagnostics are possible with ITS sequences (201). However, application of this technique as a gold standard for melanized fungi is still in dispute. In some genera, such as Alternaria and Curvularia, closely related species often cannot be distinguished on the basis of the ITS locus alone, but an optimal level of resolution can be achieved by adding information on other loci, such as the glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase or RNA polymerase II second largest subunit (98, 101, 102, 202). In contrast, ITS-based species distinction with chaetothyrialean black yeasts generally provides satisfactory results (22, 146, 203). For some genera, such as Sporothrix, sequencing of the calmodulin gene is useful to gain resolution of species within the complex (87, 89, 90). In Scedosporium (75, 76) and Phaeoacremonium (187), β-tubulin gene sequencing is used for this purpose. Considering that ITS sequences allow the identification of only about 75% of the known clinically relevant fungi, a curated database with sequences of the translational elongation factor 1α was recently proposed for use as a secondary barcode (204). A review of DNA sequence-based identification of fungi was published by Hibbet et al. (201).

In recent years, some studies have assessed the usefulness of matrix-assisted laser desorption ionization–time-of-flight mass spectrometry (MALDI-TOF MS) in the identification of filamentous fungi. These studies, reviewed by Sanguinetti and Posteraro (205), give overall rates of correct identification of 72 to 98.8%. MALDI-TOF MS identification has been studied in relatively few dematiaceous genera, such as Exophiala (206–208), Lomentospora, and Scedosporium (209), with promising results. However, this technique sometimes fails to discriminate phylogenetically closely related species, e.g., Exophiala dermatitidis from E. phaeomuriformis (207). Furthermore, commercial platforms have not provided reference mass spectrum databases covering the diversity of dematiaceous pathogens properly. A study by Singh et al. (210) evaluated MALDI-TOF MS in the identification of clinically relevant dematiaceous fungi isolated in 19 medical centers in India over a 4-year period. DNA sequence-based identifications revealed the presence of 29 dematiaceous pathogens, of which only six (20%) could be identified by MALDI-TOF MS with the commercial database of Bruker Daltonics (Bremen, Germany). An in-house database made the identification of 20 of the remaining isolates possible. In a recent study by Rychert et al. (211), correct species-level identification was achieved by MALDI-TOF in 205/325 clinical isolates of dematiaceous fungi, including Alternaria alternata, Curvularia (Bipolaris) hawaiiensis, Curvularia (Bipolaris) spicifera, Exserohilum rostratum, Exophiala dermatitidis, Exophiala xenobiotica, Cladophialophora bantiana, Scedosporium apiospermum, S. boydii, Lomentospora prolificans, and Sporothrix schenckii complex. As pointed out by Sanguinetti and Posteraro (205), comprehensive online databases are necessary for the widespread application of MALDI-TOF in the identification of filamentous fungal pathogens.

sect2.title: TYPING SYSTEMS
sect2.para: A diversity of high-resolution molecular typing systems has been developed in recent decades. These have been applied mainly to epidemiological tracking of fungal pathogens in the hospital and the community but also to showing geographical differences among isolates and to detecting cryptic species. Whole genomes and comparative genomic studies have been published for many important dematiaceous pathogens in recent years.

sect1.title: Botryosphaeriales
sect1.para: Multilocus typing at four loci demonstrated the existence of at least five different sequence types in isolates ofNeoscytalidium dimidiatum, of which two were detected exclusively in isolates from plants, two were found only in clinical isolates, and one was observed in isolates from humans and from a mango tree. The plant has been proposed as the possible source of infection in a case of mycetoma in an agricultural field worker and should be considered a potential reservoir of pathogenic strains of the fungus (212).

Whole genomes have been sequenced and published forLasiodiplodia theobromae (213), Macrophomina phaseolina (214), and Neoscytalidium dimidiatum (215). Transcriptome and proteome analyses in L. theobromae revealed that genes involved in pathogenicity to plants, such as those involved in plant cell wall degradation and toxin production, were more abundantly expressed at 25°C, while certain genes related to human disease, including virulence protein SSD1, involved in resistance to host antimicrobial peptides were expressed only at 37°C (213).

sect1.title: Capnodiales
sect1.para: The whole genome ofHortaea werneckii was sequenced by Romeo et al. (216).

sect1.title: Cladosporiales
sect1.para: The genome of a clinical strain ofCladosporium sphaerospermum, isolated from blood, was recently published (217).

sect1.title: Chaetothyriales
sect1.para: On the basis of a multigene phylogeny, it has been demonstrated that important phenotypic features have evolved independently several times in the order Chaetothyriales and that most of the clinically relevant species ofCladophialophora belong to a monophyletic group comprising two main clades (carrionii and bantiana clades) (28).

In a study that investigated the molecular diversity of oligotrophic and neurotropic members of the genusExophiala with ITS sequences and M-13 fingerprint and SSU intron data, two main groups could be distinguished within E. dermatitidis. Most environmental strains were placed in one of these groups, while the clinical strains were in the second one. Interestingly, strains from East Asia that clustered in the clinical group caused severe brain and disseminated infections, and strains of the same group recovered from outside East Asia caused only a relatively mild fungemia (39).

The natural niche ofFonsecaea species causing chromoblastomycosis in humans remains elusive. To elucidate where and how patients acquire the infection, probably through traumatic inoculation, numerous isolates with Fonsecaea-like morphology from environmental sources were typed with randomly amplified polymorphic DNA methods. The results revealed a high degree of strain diversity and showed that most strains isolated from environments to which symptomatic human patients were exposed were found to be more closely related to species of Cladophialophora than to Fonsecaea (46). Recently, Voidaleski et al. (218) used a rolling circle amplification approach to detect the environmental presence of the two main agents of chromoblastomycosis in northern Brazil, Fonsecaea pedrosoi and F. monophora. These authors analyzed 87 samples of soil and plant material collected in the environment where patients with this disease lived. Surprisingly, none of the samples tested positive for the studied pathogens.

Teixeira et al. (219) sequenced and annotated the whole genomes of 23 strains of Chaetothyriales, including medically relevant taxa such as Cladophialophora bantiana, C. carrionii, C. immunda, Exophiala dermatitidis, E. oligosperma, E. spinifera, E. mesophila, E. xenobiotica, Fonsecaea pedrosoi and Rhinocladiella mackenziei, as well as environmental members of this order, such as Capronia coronata, Capronia epimyces, and Cladophialophora yegresii. Genome sizes varied markedly among taxa, the largest belonging to members of the bantiana clade. Agents of chromoblastomycosis and phaeohyphomycosis showed a general reduction in carbohydrate-degrading enzymes but expansion of proteases. Several pathways to melanin synthesis were identified, and strains of Cladophialophora and Fonsecaea species showed a single copy of the MAT1-1 or MAT1-2 gene, indicating heterothallism. The whole genome of Arthrocladium fulminans was recently published by Moreno et al. (220).

sect1.title: Diaporthales
sect1.para: The whole genome ofDiaporthe longicolla was recently sequenced by Li et al. (221).

sect1.title: Dothideales
sect1.para: Gostinčar et al. (222) analyzed the whole genomes of 50 strains of Aureobasidium pullulans from different geographic origins and substrates in order to determine if intraspecific genomic diversification could be associated with the adaptation of this fungus to different habitats. That study revealed that A. pullulans is a generalist with a high level of recombination and no substantial specialization to any habitat at the genomic level.

sect1.title: Microascales
sect1.para: In numerous molecular studies, there has been a high genetic diversity among isolates ofScedosporium from different origins (reviewed in reference 179). However, multilocus sequence analyses have shown that such variability could be explained by the existence of numerous cryptic species in the Pseudallescheria boydii complex (75–77). In contrast, in L. prolificans, genetic variation seems to be low or absent.
The whole genomes ofLomentospora prolificans, Scedosporium apiospermum, S. boydii, and S. dehoogii were recently sequenced (223–226).

sect1.title: Ophiostomatales
sect1.para: WithSporothrix, as with Scedosporium, numerous molecular studies (reviewed in reference 88) have proven the existence of a high level of intraspecific variability, with isolates mainly grouped according to their geographical origins. However, recent multilocus studies have demonstrated that S. schenckii sensu lato comprises several phylogenetic species and morphospecies with a marked geographical distribution; i.e., S. brasiliensis isolates are mainly found in Brazil (87, 91) and, more recently, in Argentina (92), whereas clinical isolates from India predominantly belong to S. globosa (87, 89, 90). This is likely correlated with the genetic and morphological diversity shown within S. schenckii by many authors.

Whole-genome comparisons of 16 clinical and environmentalSporothrix species revealed that the clinically relevant species S. schenckii, S. brasiliensis, S. globosa, and S. luriei show significantly smaller genomes than their nonpathogenic saprobic counterparts. The absent genes are involved in the breakdown of complex carbohydrates and proteins required for wood decay, as well as other genes involved in reduced virulence (227).

sect1.title: Pleosporales
sect1.para: DNA sequence data were used to assess the origin of a large outbreak of iatrogenic CNS infections caused byExserohilum rostratum. The infections originated from contaminated vials of methylprednisolone produced by New England Compounding Center (NECC). Whole-genome sequencing was used to detect single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs), and the sequences obtained were subjected to phylogenetic analyses, including 22 isolates from patients affected with meningitis and other infections, six isolates from contaminated NECC vials, and seven isolates unrelated to the outbreak. All isolates related to the outbreak showed almost identical genomes of 33.8 Mb, with a total of eight SNPs detected, but no more than two SNPs separating any two of the 28 genomes. These genomes were separated from that of an E. rostratum strain unrelated to the outbreak by about 136,000 SNPs (228).

sect2.title: SEROLOGIC TESTS
sect2.para: A latex agglutination test is commercially available (Immuno-Mycologics Inc., Norman, OK) for detecting antibodies againstS. schenckii, particularly in disseminated cases; but despite a study (229) reporting a sensitivity of 90 to 94% and a specificity of 95 to 100%, the test has not been used widely. However, the detection of antibodies was demonstrated to be useful in the diagnosis of CNS sporotrichosis in several patients when culture-based diagnosis had failed (230).

sect1.title: In vitro
sect1.para: The availablein vitro antifungal susceptibility testing data for dematiaceous fungi are increasing every day, and, in general, the antifungal susceptibilities of the most clinically relevant species are known. However, interpretive breakpoints have not been defined, and clinical correlation data are practically nonexistent.

Amphotericin B generally has goodin vitro activity against most clinically important dematiaceous fungi, such as Exophiala (231) and Alternaria (232). However, some species have been consistently resistant in vitro, including Scedosporium spp. and Microascus paisii (163, 233, 234). The azoles, in general, have demonstrated the most consistent in vitro activity against dematiaceous fungi (reviewed in reference 127) apart from L. prolificans (235).

The newer triazoles posaconazole and voriconazole have a broad spectrum of activity, being active against most of the fungi included in this chapter. The activities of these triazoles against agents of chromoblastomycosis (236) and Pseudallescheria boydii complex (235) were similar. The activity of posaconazole is higher than that of voriconazole against Alternaria spp. (232), Exophiala spp. (231), and Sporothrix spp. (237), although against the last, the activity of both drugs was very poor. Voriconazole was highly effective and considered the drug of choice during an outbreak of iatrogenic Exserohilum rostratum CNS infections in the United States (238). Isavuconazole has shown good in vitro activity against various dematiaceous pathogens, including species of Alternaria, Bipolaris, Cladosporium, Curvularia, Exophiala, Fonsecaea, and Phialophora, but not against Scedosporium spp. and Lomentospora prolificans (239). Terbinafine showed a clear fungicidal activity in vitro against filamentous fungi. Studies of in vitro activity against dematiaceous fungi are emerging, and fairly broad-spectrum activity is seen, including against Alternaria and Curvularia (127). Echinocandins appear to have variable and species-dependent fungistatic activities for the dematiaceous fungi (240). Micafungin has demonstrated some moderate activity against Scedosporium spp. (234). The in vitro activities of the available antifungal drugs against selected dematiaceous fungi were reviewed by Revankar and Sutton (127).

sect1.title: In Vivo in Animal Models
sect1.para: Based on the small number of clinical cases produced by most of the fungi discussed in this chapter, the ideal treatment regimen against the infections that most of them produce is not yet known. Therefore, studies using different animal models have been designed to evaluate efficacy and/or corroborate the results obtainedin vitro. Animal studies have demonstrated that posaconazole is generally the most effective against infections by less common moulds, including some of those included in this chapter (reviewed by Guarro [241]).

sect2.title: Chromoblastomycosis
sect2.para: Recent studies using animal models of chromoblastomycosis that tested athymic mice demonstrated that posaconazole showed higher efficacy than the recommended drugs itraconazole and terbinafine against infections byFonsecaea pedrosoi (242) and Cladophialophora carrionii (243); voriconazole did not work against the former species.

sect2.title: Scedosporiosis and Lomentospora prolificans infections
sect2.para: Voriconazole and posaconazole, but not amphotericin B, showed efficacy that correlated within vitro MICs against Scedosporium apiospermum, S. aurantiacum, and S. boydii. No drug has shown efficacy against Lomentospora prolificans infections. The effects of double or triple antifungal drug combinations were tested against L. prolificans murine infections, and micafungin plus voriconazole or amphotericin B was the most effective, being able to prolong mouse survival and to reduce fungal load in the kidneys and brain. The combination of all three drugs was ineffective (244). In a few clinical cases, the combination of terbinafine and voriconazole demonstrated synergy and favorable results (182).

sect2.title: Phaeohyphomycosis
sect2.para: Different animal studies have evaluated the most useful antifungal drugs for treating disseminated infections produced by some clinically relevant fungi. AgainstFonsecaea monophora (245) and Exophiala dermatitidis (246), posaconazole was better than amphotericin B and itraconazole. In an experimental treatment of Neoscytalidium dimidiatum, amphotericin B worked better than voriconazole and posaconazole (247). For the treatment of Cladophialophora bantiana, murine studies tested amphotericin B, micafungin, voriconazole, flucytosine, and posaconazole alone and in double and triple combinations. The only therapeutic regimen that was able to prolong animal survival for at least 10 months was the combination of three drugs (posaconazole, micafungin, and flucytosine) (248).

sect2.title: Sporotrichosis
sect2.para: Posaconazole showed excellent efficacy in experimental infections against the two most common species causing sporotrichosis, i.e.,S. schenckii and S. brasiliensis (249).

sect2.title: EVALUATION, INTERPRETATION, AND REPORTING OF RESULTS
sect2.para: More than 100 species of melanized fungi have caused infection in humans and animals, and many of these are relatively rare as etiologic agents. As a result, few clinicians are familiar with these fungi, and they are frequently overlooked. Infections caused by dematiaceous fungi are being diagnosed increasingly among healthy as well as immunocompromised patients. Concurrently, the expanding diversity of etiology within this group of fungi is becoming apparent.

Determining whether a particular dematiaceous fungus is involved in a disease process can be difficult, because many of these fungi are occasionally recovered as contaminants from clinical specimens. Repeated recovery of a suspected etiologic agent is significant, while DNA sequence identity of clinical material and the isolate is highly supportive. Isolation of a dematiaceous fungus from a normally sterile body site should not be dismissed as contamination, particularly if colonies are numerous or more than one culture plate shows growth. If isolated from a nonsterile pulmonary specimen, such as sputum, or bronchial lavage fluid, well-documented opportunists from genera such asCladophialophora, Fonsecaea, Scedosporium, or Verruconis, which are not seen as contaminants, also are highly indicative. Correlation between culture and histopathology results should also be determined.

Failure to order fungus culture when tissues are collected during surgical procedures is an increasing problem in the management of these infections, and clinicians should order fungus culture whenever warranted. In the future, direct identification of fungal genera from tissue blocks by immunohistochemistry,in situ DNA hybridization, or DNA sequencing will be a promising approach to rapid detection and identification of these agents.
